diagnosis.score_summary: [NOTE: Input was null, generating DEMO analysis for 'Aura Sleep']. The brand is suffering from severe schizophrenia: WWW sells a transformative health tool (Magician), while PDP sells a generic comfort item (Caregiver). This disconnect erodes pricing power and confuses the consumer.

truth_1.headline: Magic vs. Mom
truth_1.gap_description: WWW promises a transformative, almost magical health evolution. PDP promises a soft, safe, nurturing hug. You are selling a medical device on one channel and a teddy bear on the other.
truth_1.why_matters: This split personality dilutes authority. The customer expecting 'Transformation' feels underwhelmed by the 'Caregiver' product experience.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are currently straddling the line between a premium health intervention and a commodity comfort item. The data demands a choice: either downgrade the website to 'Cozy' to match the volume driving Amazon (Option A), or purge the soft language from Amazon to protect the premium 'Magician' equity (Option B). You cannot change lives and just be 'nice' at the same time.

truth_2.headline: The Innovation Erasure
truth_2.gap_description: Your website shouts about Nobel Prize technology and patents. Your PDP shouts about being a good deal. You are actively training your customers to ignore your innovation and look at the price tag.
truth_2.why_matters: When a 'Science' brand competes on price, it loses. You are turning your proprietary advantage into a generic commodity.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: Your Amazon listing is effectively apologizing for the price by hiding the technology. You must decide: either admit the tech is a gimmick and sell on price globally (Option A), or force the Amazon listing to lead with the 'Science'—even if it lowers conversion rate initially—to save the brand's margin (Option B). Innovation requires arrogance, not discounts.

truth_3.headline: The Vibe Crash
truth_3.gap_description: WWW feels like a private club for bio-hackers. PDP feels like a grocery store aisle. The dissonance makes the website feel pretentious and the Amazon page feel cheap.
truth_3.why_matters: A luxury aesthetic cannot survive a bargain-bin execution. High-value customers will churn when they see the 'Basic' reality.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: You are trying to be exclusive and accessible simultaneously, which is impossible. The hard choice is here: either democratize the brand on WWW to match the mass-market reality (Option A), or gate the Amazon experience to reflect the 'Elite' status, perhaps by removing low-tier SKUs (Option B). Exclusivity is a discipline, not a toggle.

truth_4.headline: The Polish Gap
truth_4.gap_description: Both channels aim for 'Clean & Modern', but WWW achieves a 5/5 polish while PDP slips to a 3/5. It is consistent, but the PDP degradation suggests a lack of resources or care.
truth_4.evidence: Visual Identity: WWW (5/5 Clean) vs PDP (3/5 Clean)
truth_4.why_matters: This is a silent killer. The brand looks 'real' on the site but 'knock-off' on Amazon. It erodes trust at the moment of purchase.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: Your visual identity is holding, but the execution on Amazon is fraying at the edges. You must choose: either invest in premium A+ content to match the site's fidelity (Option A), or simplify the website's design to match the rougher reality of the marketplace (Option B). A slightly messy luxury brand looks like a counterfeit.

truth_5.headline: The Engineering Anchor
truth_5.gap_description: Despite the chaos elsewhere, both channels effectively communicate 'Sleep Engineering'. This is the strongest thread connecting the two disparate experiences.
truth_5.why_matters: It proves that when the brand focuses on the product truth, it wins. This is your blueprint for fixing the rest.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: The 'Engineering' narrative is the only thing stopping total brand collapse. You should double down here. The choice is: either pivot the entire brand (Visuals, Archetypes) to align *only* with this Engineering strength (Option A), or risk losing it by trying to fix the 'Emotional' gaps (Option B). When in doubt, build on the one pillar that is actually standing.

marker_1.so_what: WWW promises transformation; PDP promises basic comfort. The 'Why' is broken.

marker_2.so_what: Vision is diluted from 'Revolutionizing Health' to just 'Better Rest'.

marker_3.so_what: High consistency on Quality standards holds the brand together.

marker_4.so_what: You are positioning as 'Luxury Science' on WWW but 'Commodity' on PDP.

marker_5.so_what: The personality shifts from 'Visionary Leader' to 'Nice Neighbor'.

marker_6.so_what: Complete archetype clash. 'Magician' (WWW) vs 'Caregiver' (PDP) creates confusion.

marker_7.so_what: Tone is surprisingly stable, though PDP is slightly less formal.

marker_8.so_what: Visuals are stable, but WWW is more 'Polished' than PDP.

marker_9.so_what: Key messages around engineering are making it through to PDP.

marker_10.so_what: The story shifts from 'The Lab' (Science) to 'The Bedroom' (Utility).

marker_11.so_what: WWW sells the technology; PDP sells the shipping speed. Value is lost.

marker_12.so_what: A dangerous pivot from 'Proprietary Tech' to 'Cheap Price'.

marker_13.so_what: WWW focuses on Outcome; PDP gets stuck in Features.

marker_14.so_what: Both channels agree the product provides 'Deep Sleep'. Ideally consistent.

marker_15.so_what: WWW sells 'Empowerment'; PDP sells 'Relief'. Defensive vs Offensive.

marker_16.so_what: You look like a luxury brand on WWW and a generic brand on PDP.

marker_17.so_what: WWW invites you to a 'Movement'; PDP sells a lonely pillow.
